sen.j: 五品江戸廻送令（ごひんえどかいそうれい）は、江戸幕府が1860年（万延元年）に発令した生糸・雑穀・水油・蝋・呉服を対象とした貿易統制法令。
sen.e: Law for Transporting Five Articles through Edo was the law for trading control over raw silk thread, cereals, hair oil, wax and draperies issued by the Edo bakufu in 1860.

The Law for Transporting Five Articles through Edo was a law for trading control over raw silk thread, cereals, hair oil, wax and draperies issued by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in 1860.
sen.cmt: 文頭にTheを追加、the law→a lawとし、bakufuの補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 日米修好通商条約や安政五カ国条約の締結により、1859年（安政6年）から函館港・横浜港・長崎港の3港で貿易が開始し、港に居留する外国商人と日本の商人との間で取引が行われるようになった。
sen.e: Following the conclusion of Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan as well as Ansei commercial treaties, trade started in 3 ports such as Hakodate Port, Yokohama Port and Nagasaki Port from 1859, and merchants in Japan began to have dealings with foreign merchants living in these ports.

Following the conclusion of the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan as well as the Ansei Commercial Treaties, trade started in three ports such as Hakodate Port, Yokohama Port and Nagasaki Port from 1859, and merchants in Japan began to have dealings with foreign merchants living in these ports.
sen.cmt: the Treaty of Amity and Commerce、the Ansei Commercial Treatiesとし、3をスペルアウトしました。
sen.e: Following the conclusion of the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan as well as the Ansei Commercial Treaties, trade started in three ports such as Hakodate Port, Yokohama Port and Nagasaki Port from 1859, and merchants in Japan began to have dealings with foreign merchants living in these ports.

sen.j: 日本からは主に生糸が輸出されたが、生糸などの輸出品は、国内市場よりも貿易市場の方が高値で取引されていたため、生産地と市場を仲立ちしていた在郷商人は、江戸などの大都市の問屋ではなく、直接、開港場へ生産品を卸すようになった。
sen.e: Japanese main export was raw silk thread, and because exported goods such as raw silk thread were exchanged at higher prices on the trading market than on the domestic market, local merchants, who mediated between a place of production and market, began to sell products wholesale directly at open ports, not to warehouse merchants in big cities such as Edo (now Tokyo).

sen.j: そのため、江戸の問屋商人を中心とする従来の流通機構が徐々にほころびを見せ始めた。
sen.e: Therefore, traditional distribution system led by wholesalers in Edo began to collapse.

sen.j: さらに太平天国の乱へのイギリス・フランスの介入が本格化すると、本来ならば需要がない筈の雑穀や蝋などの軍需品の輸出の増加も始まった。
sen.e: Moreover, when the intervention in Taiping Rebellion by England and France intensified, there was an increased demand for exports of war supplies such as cereals and wax that was originally not in demand.

sen.cmt: 統一事項に基づき、Taiping Rebellion→the Taiping Warに修正、that was→which wereとし、カンマ追加しました。

sen.j: こうした、急増する輸出需要に対し、生産供給が追いつかず、全般的に物価が高騰するなど、日本経済に大きな混乱が生じていた。
sen.e: Rapidly increased demand for exports far exceeded the supply of production, while prices of commodity soared in general, throwing Japan's economy into great confusion.

sen.j: こうした事態に対応するため、江戸の問屋商人らの要望も受けた江戸幕府は、1860年に、生糸、雑穀、水油、蝋、呉服の五品目について、必ず江戸の問屋を経由する法令 - 五品江戸廻送令 - を発出した。
sen.e: To deal with such situation, and in response to the wishes of wholesalers in Edo the Edo bakufu issued the law providing that merchants never fail to get through the warehouse merchants in Edo regarding five articles such as raw silk thread, cereals, hair oil, wax and draperies in 1860.

To deal with such situation, and in response to the wishes of wholesalers in Edo the Edo bakufu issued the Law for Transporting Five Articles through Edo, which was a law providing that merchants never failed to get through the warehouse merchants in Edo regarding five articles such as raw silk thread, cereals, hair oil, wax and draperies in 1860.
sen.cmt: the law→a law、fail→failedとし、「五品江戸廻送令」→訳漏れのため訳出しました。

sen.j: この法令は、江戸問屋の保護と物価高騰の抑制を目的としていたが、すぐに列強各国から、条約に規定する自由貿易を妨げる、と強い反発を受けた。
sen.e: Although this law was intended to protect warehouse merchants in Edo and to control steep price rise, it immediately met with strong opposition from powerful countries insisting that the law would hamper free trade policy as specified in Treaty.

Although this law was intended to protect warehouse merchants in Edo and to control steep price rise, it immediately met with strong opposition from powerful countries insisting that the law would hamper free trade policy as specified in the treaties.
sen.cmt: in Treaty→in the treatiesとしました。

sen.j: また、在郷商人らも依然として港へ直接廻送を続けたため、法令の効果はあがらなかった。
sen.e: In addition because local merchants still continued to directly transport goods to open ports, the law did not produce satisfactory results.

sen.j: 1862年（文久2年）には抜け道として生糸の代わりに輸出が増加した原料である蚕紙の輸出禁止を命じたものの、こちらも列強の圧力によって1年で廃止されている。
sen.e: In 1862 instead of raw silk thread its material a silkworm-egg card, which increased in exports, was prohibited from exporting as a secret passage, but this was also abolished under the pressure from powerful countries in a year.

sen.j: だが、開国の反動から攘夷鎖国への傾向が出てきたことを背景に、1863年（文久3年）から、幕府は同法令の本格施行を強め、その結果、生糸輸出が減少するなど次第に実効が現れていった。
sen.e: However, supported by the trend toward expulsion of foreigners and national isolation arising in reaction to the opening of country to the world, the bakufu promoted full-fledged enforcement of the law from 1863, and as a result it began to produce material results slowly such as the decreased exports of raw silk thread.

sen.j: しかし、1864年（元治元年）の下関戦争を契機として、列強各国は幕府へ同法令の撤回を強く迫り、一方幕府内部からも生糸の輸出に税金をかける形で抑制した方が幕府財政の改善にも繋がるとする意見も出された。
sen.e: However, prompted by the Shimonoseki War in 1864, powerful countries heavily pressed the Edo bakufu for the abolition of the law while there were opinions within the Edo bakufu that it would lead to the improved financial affairs of bakufu and be wiser to keep trading under control by imposing tax on exports of raw silk thread.

sen.j: このため、幕府も開国の流れを止めるのは得策でないと判断し、実質的に同法令は放棄されることとなった。
sen.e: Therefore, the Edo bakufu judged that it would not be good policy to stop the trend toward the opening of country to the world, and eventually the law was abolished.

sen.e: Subsequently in 1865 the Edo bakufu established the system for changing a seal on raw silk thread and silkworm-egg card, and it placed producers of silkworm-egg card and raw silk thread under an obligation to pay myogakin (money to dedicate).

sen.e: Nevertheless, this policy was continued even after the establishment of the Meiji government, and in 1873 the government proclaimed the regulation for controlling the production of raw silk thread, putting producers under an obligation to affix a revenue stamp in the shipment of raw silk thread.

sen.e: After that, the Meiji government became more and more involved in increased production, and export policy of raw silk thread in terms of encouragement of new industry and Shizoku jusan (providing shizoku with employment).
